articles.title: There's No Such Thing as a Climate Haven
articles.author: Julie Arbit
articles.summary: In 2024, extreme weather shattered any illusion of shelter, even in places far from ever-flooding coasts and the parched, wildfire-plagued Southwest. The concept originated in 2018 when real estate experts touted northeastern and Great Lakes cities as reliable, safe destinations. These safe spaces are mostly insulated from tropical storms, and isolated from the immediate dangers of coastal erosion and sea level rise.

articles.title: Poor regions suffer more from extreme weather
articles.author: Joachim Klement
articles.summary: Extreme weather caused by climate change hurts poorer countries more than richer ones. Research shows that even within rich and temperate Europe, extreme weather events hurt countries with lower GDP per capita more than rich parts of the continent. An 0.1-point increase in the E3CI on average reduces GDP/capita by 0.25%.

Coastal erosion, rapid land subsidence, and rising sea levels have displaced many families and damaged vast areas of rice fields and aquaculture ponds. The Government of Indonesia has shown growing interest in hybrid coastal protection approaches, combining engineered solutions with the services provided by natural ecosystems.

articles.title: Ahmedabad plane crash: How is extreme heat affecting air travel?

articles.summary: The sandhill crane is among Minnesota's largest bird species. Sandhills are birds of wet meadows and open landscapes. They migrate south for the winter and stand about five feet tall and have a wingspan of nearly seven feet. They are among the largest birds of Minnesota.

articles.author: Marilyn Perkins
articles.summary: Every year, billions of birds migrate in and out of the United States and across the world. They use a variety of cues to keep their migratory direction. Sight and smell are two basic cues that birds use to find their way. They also use the sun and stars as guides.

New Hampshire would get a long reprieve from allergies during snowy cold winters but now the cold and snow are holding off longer and melting away sooner. The net effect is more pollen in the air for longer periods.
